ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I improved my translation skills by leaps and bounds. I was able to put into practice the ideas discussed in supplemental readings on translation theory written by a range of thinkers throughout history. Professor Gleisner's weekly feedback was also very helpful for my growth as a translator.
Working knowledge of various translation theories and practices (foreignized vs domesticated translation, syntactic faithfulness, metrical thoughtfulness, capturing the 'essence' of an author).
Grammatical, political, and cultural theories on translation

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Really liked the course and professor. There truly are mostly strengths in this course, but the one weakness is that sometimes the readings for each class were super dense/boring.
Strengths: Great feedback on assignments, texts on the syllabus were well-chosen and interesting, peer work and workshopping of translations was helpful. Weaknesses: N/A.

Most of the texts we had to translate each week were really enjoyable! Our discussions with the rest of the class about how each translation went and what choices we made were quite insightful. The readings paired really well with each week's assignment. The one thing I wish had been done differently is that we spent most of class going over the theoretical reading for the weekI would have preferred spending more time workshopping/peer editing in class.

Strengths - great variety of texts to translate, Professor Gleisner really cared about making sure we were understanding the material/growing as translators

Weaknesses - high workload at times

Great midterm and final project with freedom for students to explore authors.

Discussions were slow and not greatly facilitated. Not enough structure.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would certainly recommend this course to any French student interested in translation.
Yes if you have a strong level of French (at least in terms of reading)! Just don't procrastinate on the midterm and final projects.
Yes. It's a great introduction to translation theory.
